intro: Mezilaurus quadrilocellata, commonly known as the four-chambered mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its evergreen, leathery leaves and small, white or pale yellow flowers. The plant forms dense clusters on the branches of its host trees, primarily oaks and hickories, and relies on its host for water and nutrients while performing photosynthesis. Its fruits are small, fleshy berries that attract birds, which in turn aid in seed dispersal. Mezilaurus quadrilocellata plays an important ecological role in its habitat, contributing to biodiversity and supporting various wildlife species.
